results.title: Talking of teeth
results.creator_credit: R.D. Hansen and Fortune Film Productions
results.brief_description: Examines the causes of dental decay, the effects of badly spaced teeth, the structure and care of teeth, and the value of visits to the dentist. Stresses the cultivation of the correct attitude to teeth care.
results.description: Examines the causes of dental decay, the effects of badly spaced teeth, the structure and care of teeth, and the value of visits to the dentist. Stresses the cultivation of the correct attitude to teeth care.

results.title: Talking of safety
results.creator_credit: Ron Tanner, David Evans and Millbank Films
results.brief_description: Deals with the effectiveness of safety committee meetings. Shows how a newly-appointed safety supervisor at a brick and tile manufacturing plant in England makes his committee work more effectively while promoting clearly defined objectives.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ron Tanner, David Evans and Millbank Films

results.title: Talking heads by Alan Bennett
results.creator_credit: Tristram Powell, Alan Bennett, Giles Foster, Stuart Burge, Innes Lloyd and BBC
results.brief_description: Six monologues (each approx. 36 mins.) written by Alan Bennett and delivered by five of Britain’s most auspicious female actors (Patricia Routledge, Maggie Smith, Julie Walters, Thora Hird, Stephanie Cole) and Bennett himself. Made for television and originally screened in Britain in 1987, each piece displays the wry observations, knowing irony and tender understatement that are characteristic of Bennett’s writing style. The suburban normality of the world his characters inhabit belies their lives of secrets, revelations, fears, crimes and passions. They tell their stories, and in doing so reveal more than they know of the humour, passion and sadness of their lives.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tristram Powell, Alan Bennett, Giles Foster, Stuart Burge, Innes Lloyd and BBC

results.title: Talking hands 2. Parts 18-25 (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Viewers are introduced to signed English by teaching signs for 300 words most commonly used. Includes practice with short sentences. The vocabulary of the original Talking Hands is extended by 400 signs in Talking Hands 2.

results.title: Talking about kitchens
results.creator_credit: Gerry Poulson and Gerard Holdsworth Productions
results.brief_description: Gilbert Harding explains how thought and planning, both in the new kitchen and when renovating an old one, can result in more convenient arrangement of benches, stove, dish-washing machine and sink, making work easier and less tiring. Shows how the basic principles of planning can be applied to a great variety of circumstances.

Shows how the basic principles of planning can be applied to a great variety of circumstances.
